name: asherdan
text: A comment left by asherdan was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by Norsef, UntilYouAreSoNude, littlecat, riotdejaneiro, mikeronomicon, StoatLad, Thorfinn, wildcat, aargh, DiamondMonster, Catachresis, bug, theoneyouwant, antecen, robbingdog, NDCaesar, SoManyWhales, atticusonline, Art-Vader, luckypyjamas, lk, werthog42, genocidefish, bixschmix, Herr_Modin, stormagnet, dj_douche, Pigs)

name: evilbobikus
text: A comment left by evilbobikus was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by thedice, littlecat, fakead, Art-Vader)

name: notgodot
text: Asherdan comments get hella lamed because he bitches about like every strip ever.

name: evilbobikus
text: Yeah, but I really don't see that many times where the comment itself is worth that many lames, outside of it being Asherdan and being on top of the page makes it an easy target.

name: lolsworth
text: If you act like an unpardonable douche 98% of the time then you're still going to get a kick in the cock the other 2% on general principles

name: catachresis
text: Oh god this is just completely prime Roast Beef (NPI). This is just fucking gold.

name: catachresis
text: A comment left by catachresis was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by fakead, sevenarts, rascaldom, farqussus)

name: jonnay
text: Prince is NOTORIOUS for owning shoes.

name: jthm_guitarist
text: He refers to Prince as 'what' instead of 'who'.

name: slab64
text: Exactly.

name: delzhand
text: I love this one so much.  I've used panel 4 many times.

name: hellofyellin
text:
"Don't get me wrong, Olive Oil has a place. That place is at the store while you are buying butter."

Myriad applications.

name: featurelessvoid
text: It's true; Popeye hates to go grocery shopping alone.

name: joestork
text: So lame, it's a chubby

name: dejavroom
text:
"Shoes which are still at the store and not sold and I am driving away at kind of an angle to the store"

this is borderline DFW-ian dialogue. RB has no idea of how much class he packs.

name: stuart
text: Dallas-Fort Worth?

name: relaxing
text: David Foster Wallace.

name: kilroywashere
text: Surely, you Jest.

name: rowboat
text: "DFW-ian dialogue" (ugh....why would you even write it that way?) does not equal class, sir. It equals pretentiousness.

name: crev_gibax
text: It equals the pretense of class.

name: dejavroom
text: Watch me as I disagree with you.

name: boredom_man
text: We can't. We all fell asleep trying to read David Foster Wallace.

name: fermatprime
text: Chubby on the assumption that that's a DFW quote, despite my not being able to remember from what.

name: woodenteeth
text:
David Foster Wallace isn't pretentious. The guy is hilarious. It's all meta-comedy and just basically fucking with the way you read and the way people write. He gets conceptual on our asses. If you don't like that kinda thing you shouldn't be reading it, it's just a different art form.

We still bros though, yeah, rowboat?

name: fineoakstructure
text: Some might say that "meta-comedy" and "fucking with the way you read" might be pretentious.

name: boredom_man
text: I wouldn't say it's inherently pretentious. I'd just say that for every four pages of a David Foster Wallace novel, there's a Jonathan Safran Foer one-liner. And those fucking Wallace footnotes just look like someone with OCD trying to explain the humor in The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy.

name: utv
text: R.I.P.

name: boredom_man
text: Uh, yeah... we... we still bros, dead writer-guy?

name: juanclaudius
text: The difference between Foer and Wallace is that Foer's characters are unrelatable, and he doesn't seem to care about them with depth beyond Lifetime-Original-Movie styles. Wallace is so obsessed with every tiny detail of every little thing that it's impossible, for me at least, to not join him in the hyperengagement.

name: woodenteeth
text: You sir, are correct.

name: woodenteeth
text:
Funny. I actually agree with you now.

Opinions. Hilariously pliable.

Poor DFW. I'll pour one out for you tonight homey.

name: fineoakstructure
text:
Actually, I wasn't even stating my own opinion of David Foster Wallace. Besides a short story here and there, I haven't read him, and I'm willing to remain indifferent on him until I do; I'm way too behind in books I do have to get caught in the Infinite Jest; I bought a bargain copy of Interviews with Hideous Men book but I don't know if I've ever read any of it.

I'm tempted to say I might like him; a lot of things I like (music, movies) can be described as "fucking with the way you ______," but I totally understand some people wanting to call it pretentious. They can be wrong a number of times, but they're often right.

name: woodenteeth
text:
I also find it interesting that I'm misreading many a comment to be a direct rebuttal of my tastes. Pah. You have revealed me once more. I feel like Phantom.

*disappears into the shadows*

name: fineoakstructure
text:
No, no...you were right the first time, really. It does read as a dig on your opinion. Ideally, it would've originally contained amendedment "...not that I necessarily do, but some people do, and I'm not sure that they aren't correct."

Jesus Christ can I write a direct sentence on the fucking page? Is it any wonder that I love the David Berman/Silver Jews line:

I have not avoided certainty
It has always just eluded me

name: rowboat
text:
And hopefully this is the part where the conversation changes from one about David Foster Wallace to one about David Berman and doesn't look back.

Quote:
Well, I wish they didn't set mirrors behind the bar, 'cause I can't stand to look at my face when I don't know where you are.


Now there's a talent for words that I can sink my teeth into.

name: fineoakstructure
text: The only thing that kills me about Berman is that he seems to be slipping these days.  Tanglewood Numbers was a disappointment, I thought, and, almost like the S Malkmus solo albums, his lyrics started to become too ironically corny or just straight up ham.  I've heard similar complaints about the new album; I haven't even heard it yet.

name: rowboat
text: Agreed, but I have faith (though I haven't heard the newest one either). And even if he's through, what a catalog he left behind.

name: rowboat
text:
OK, woodenteeth - "1 years" later (closer to two, I'd say) I'd like to officially reverse my stance on the work of David Foster Wallace. I humbly admit that when I made the above comment I was speaking directly out of my ass. In actuality, I hadn't at that time read enough to really have a well-informed opinion on the subject. I spoke as though I had. This was wrong. I'm sorry.

I still haven't taken a shot at Infinite Jest, but Girl With Curious Hair was amazing and the Kenyon commencement speech basically changed my life.

name: woodenteeth
text: Read all of the short stories and essays, there is much gold in there. Sometimes it takes some digging, but I often find the digging becomes part of the fun (which I'm sure was his intention). Infinite Jest is just a long series of interconnected short stories. Read it that way and you'll knock it over quite simply. I never found it that hard going, it was just too entertaining to be a chore.

name: layzerblade
text:
The "borderline" part is what bothers me. Seems to me that Chris Onstad wouldn't want his work described as an incomplete version of somebody else's, and DFW wouldn't want his work held up as a standard of perfection. Comparing Onstad to DFW is fair and could be interesting. Saying one man's writing is like a failed version of another's is kind of rude.

-=I HOPE WE ARE STILL COOL DEJAVROOM THIS IS JUST SOMETHING THAT BUGGED ME=-

name: wite_rabit
text: Dude, don't call Relaxing Shirley.

name: infinitejest
text: Someone said DFW?

name: shutup_shutup
text: I misinterpreted this comment as referring to DSW and was confused by it.

name: zem
text: Seriously, panel 4 alone gives this a 5

name: rizzle
text: An animal which represents alacrity, how can i ever take pumas again seriously?

name: zapatos
text: The shoe, or the animal?  I take neither seriously, one is a shoe and the other does not speak English.

name: dark_lemur
text:
i looked up alacrity: "a brisk and cheerful readiness."
classic.

name: teknofatcat
text: I love "driving at kind of an angle to the store," it gives me time to clear my head?

name: tekende
text: Okay, over the past few months I have read this comment probably twenty times and it still doesn't make sense to me. What the fuck are you talking about?

name: overmedicated
text: Oh! Seven-kinky!

name: tekende
text: Seriously though. "it gives me time to clear my head?" What is that??

name: centipede_damascus
text: Molly feels so bad about Beef's roughed-up feet but all he gives her is smart-aleckry.

name: junko
text: Molly's kind of WTF face in the last panel is really funny.

name: crinklebat
text: "shoes that have a design on the side for which I am assessed a premium" made me spit coffee on myself the first time I read it.

name: philosophe
text: This is my favorite strip, probably because Roast Beef is my favorite character.

name: lrosetw8
text: Yay, their lamp is a better one!

name: stormagnet
text: Yeah, slow down Molly! He can only take so much change at once!

name: chrissketch
text: This the first time I've noticed that Beef tucks the sheets underneath himself.

name: xiaomimi
text:
Today's Blogs

Ray: A Dream.
Pat: The way they sell celery is RIDICULOUS.
Philippe: Oh! I want to be President!
Lyle: Yeah it was his 02 sensor

name: historyandmetal
text:
remember when you made those little shoe box diarama of like the plains and the africa, like? and you were supposed to show how the cheetah would like hide in the bushes or go and get some water but then also sometimes rip like ribs and bladders out of the zebras? But then you'd wait till the last minute and fake it all and say the cheetahs were hiding in the pine cone you used as a bush and you'd still get a B anyways cause like who fails 3rd grade?

Yeah this strip is like when you looked through the little peephole of your neighbor's diarama shoe box and it was like watching winston churchill and F.D.R. play hopscotch when they were both five. Just brilliant and perfect and all like that.

name: redmange
text: I enjoy shoes that have a resistance to liquids that I am never likely to step in.

name: sp1derbaby
text: Give it a few years.

name: atticusonline
text: 5 for alacrity!

name: shutup_shutup
text: 5 to Alacrity!

name: shutup_shutup
text: Assetbar didn't like my plus sign so that didn't make much sense.  This was supposed to be a D&D joke.

name: lechatbotte
text:
I have the hardest time finding Beef's voice. Sometimes he's all hip and cool, and then he bust out lines like these, and "alacrity" to boot!

How could you not love a strip that throws that one out as casually as a convienence store hot dog?

name: laserblade
text: This is the first hint of shoe-based eroticism between Molly and Beef.

name: arelladawn
text: I need to find my cat a girlfriend along these lines... or maybe he already has one and is just waiting to die or for her to reanimate

name: farqussus
text: You need to find your cat a girlfriend who wants him to wear shoes?

name: arelladawn
text: Not quite, but one that would try to cheer him up and not be put off by his fickle but generally subdued personality.  He's been grumping around way too much lately.

name: farqussus
text:
Fickle but generally subdued would describe every cat I've ever met.

I don't want to appear rude, but cat owners seem more susceptible to anthropomorphism than any other pet owners.

name: carlyle
text: I will use the last line when someone asks me what kind of shoes I like. Which is not often. My most recent pair were picked without my knowing and appeared where my old ones were.

name: johnnybaverage
text: Right now I'm listening to "No Children" by the Mountain Goats and it's more than a little depressing to read any Beef & Molly interactions with that in the background.
